poem:
**The Director's Hand**

In the frame's quiet shadow,  
Neame's hand guides the light,  
etching an Oscar's path,  
whispering 'Bravo, Miss Brodie'  
where disagreements dance  
like ghosts on the set.  
Maggie strides in the spotlight,  
adorned in accolades,  
yet behind the curtain's fold,  
a director's unseen touch.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Letter: Dame Maggie Smith obituary In his fine obituary of Dame Maggie Smith, Michael Coveney includes many of the names of the film directors she worked with. However, for her “iconic performance in The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie”, there is no mention of Ronald Neame (about whom I am writing a book). Smith acknowledged the debt she owed to Neame in directing her to her first Oscar – though they did not always agree". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
